DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: ... a sister
DOC.TEXT: Alejandro Manrique Lozano, 30, of Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., called his wife from Fort Bragg, N.C., before leaving for Panama and said, ``Watch the news. I love you.'' He was an anti-armor weapons expert with the 82nd Airborne division. Manrique was a naturalized citizen born in Callao, Peru, a Lima suburb where his parents still live. He had lived in the United States for five years and enlisted for a four-year stint in the Army's elite Special Forces in January 1988. He and his wife, Sheree Nelson-Manrique, 47, met four years ago when they both were working for singer Julio Iglesias. They had no children during their 2{ years of marriage.

Markwell, 21, an Army Ranger medic from Cincinnati, died soon after U.S. forces began their assault on Panamanian military headquarters. Markwell had been stationed at Hunter Army Airfield in Savannah, Ga., ``His leave was supposed to start today (Thursday) and he was planning to come home for Christmas,'' said his stepfather, Bill Rouse, of Shannon, Ohio. ``He knew what the dangers were, but he was willing to take the chance.'' Markwell played football at Cincinnati's Princeton High, graduating in 1986, then spent two years in college studying medicine. ``He just loved people and that was the basis for his decision to become a Ranger,'' Rouse said. ``He was committed to it and planned to make a career of the military.''

McFaul, 32, died three days after his first wedding anniversary. His wife, Patricia, in Norfolk, Va., is expecting their first child. McFaul, of San Diego, Calif., was a 14-year Navy veteran and a member of the SEAL operation based at Little Creek, Va. He had been sent to Spanish language school and had assignments in the Philippines and may have gone to Central America and El Salvador.

Perez, 22, an infantryman, had been offered an honorable discharge last year when an accident caused him to loose sight in one eye, but refused because ``he wanted to be a soldier,'' said his sister, Adriana, of Pawtucket, R.I. Perez, who was born in Colombia, graduated from Central Falls High School and most of his family lives in nearby Pawtucket. He entered the Army in 1985 and had been stationed at Fort Polk, La., until being transferred to Panama on Oct. 14.

Price, sumoned to Panama eight days ago, would have turned 23 on Christmas Eve. He was a paratrooper in the Army's 75th Rangers. Price, of Conover, Wis., joined the Army in July 1988 for its college fund when he could not continue his education at Olivet Nazarene College in Illinois. His two younger brothers also joined the Army to earn college money after their father died of a heart attack three years ago. He is also survived by his mother, Ruth Ann, and a sister. Friends remembered him as polite, outgoing, jovial and hard-working. He loved the outdoors and fishing.

Rodriguez, 24, of Missouri City, Texas, near Houston, was a six-year Navy veteran. He is originally from Los Angeles. He joined the SEAL Delivery Vehicle Team II in Little Creek, Va., in March 1985, and went to basic underwater demolition school in Coronado, Calif., last year. Rodriguez returned to Little Creek in January and was assigned to the Naval Special Warfare Group II.

Roth, 19, of Killeen, Texas, was a military policeman stationed at Fort Hood, Texas. He was married to another soldier, Spec. Mary Roth, also stationed at Fort Hood. The couple wed shortly after Roth graduated from Rockridge High School in Illinois in 1988, said his father-in-law, Donald Ziegenhorn, of Illinois City, Ill.Roth entered the Army in September 1988.

_Pvt. 2 Kenneth Douglas Scott, 20, of Princeton, W.Va., joined the Army six months ago and was stationed out of Fort Polk, La. He was to marry his high school sweetheart, Yvette Howard, when he came home on leave in January. She had Christmas presents ready to mail to him. Scott was the fourth of five children. His legal guardian, Ruth Palmer, did not know he was in Panama.

Tilghman, like Connors, McFaul and Rodriguez, was a member of the Navy SEAL team who died in an assault on a Panamanian airfield. Tilghman, 30, was a native of Kailua, Hawaii, and entered the Navy in 1979. ``He was following in my footsteps. He joined right after high school,'' his father said in a telephone interview from his home in Kailua. Taylor Tilghman was in the Navy for 15 years and the Coast Guard for 15 years.
